name: NPR
text:
Avery Hoppa is still working, so she's trying to support local businesses. 

But, she says, "if I'm buying things ... that store has to be open and possibly it's putting those people at risk."

"It's just hard to figure out. What's the right thing to do?" https://t.co/7eMmADbYKQ

name: NPR
text:
The Boston Marathon has been canceled for the first time in its 124-year history.

All participants who were set to run in the event will be eligible to participate in an online alternative.
https://t.co/UzjALVYZFV

name: NPR
text:
Mike Penceâ€™s chief of staff owns as much as $1.6 million worth of stocks in companies linked to coronavirus response.

He declared some to be possible conflicts of interest but hasn't divested from them.

"This is now a red alarm," said an ethics watchdog. https://t.co/95BrXEoZUq

name: NPR
text:
We love seeing new faces in the Tiny Desk Contest each year â€” but it's exciting to recognize the artists who come back time after time, giving us a little view into their growth as musicians. 

Here's a playlist of our favorite returning artistsðŸ‘‡ https://t.co/udKYcg0nID

name: NPR
text:
Taking "slow and low" breaths through the nose can help relieve stress and reduce blood pressure, notes journalist James Nestor. 

"When we breathe through our mouths, we're denying our bodies the ability to do this." 
https://t.co/Yr8cwesOTI

text:

Here are scenes from the protests in Minneapolis and Los Angeles following George Floyd's death.

text:
NEW: The National Guard confirmed it is deploying more than 500 soldiers to Minneapolis, St. Paul and surrounding areas, adding "a key objective is to ensure fire departments are able to respond to calls."
https://t.co/TEWKKmiMPs

name: NPR
text: Local and federal officials are growing increasingly concerned about Fourth of July events on the National Mall. President Trump has made no indication he plans to cancel the annual celebration. @wamu885 https://t.co/F58kZ1jXr8

name: NPR
text: Questlove isn't letting a pandemic slow him down. The Roots drummer, DJ and cookbook author is adding one more thing to his resume â€” virtual potluck dinner host. https://t.co/oGYUy2YS8K

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: Flames are ravaging the Third Precinct police building in Minneapolis, which has been a focal point of demonstrations over George Floyd's death. A police spokesperson says personnel there are safe. https://t.co/z4mujsI9Bo

name: NPR
text:
New Yorkers Gali Beeri and Joshua Boliver met in March as the city was about to lock down. 

Then the near-strangers took a leap of faith to ride out quarantine in Joshua's apartment.
https://t.co/JAQlmQLHGF

text: Weâ€™re answering your questions about the process to get a vaccine for the coronavirus, workplace safety and voter registration amid the pandemic. ðŸ‘‡https://t.co/51udRCNR7W

name: NPR
text: A lot of county and state fairs have been canceled because of the new coronavirus, but some Californians jonesing for fair food were able to get their fix with special drive-through to-go meals -- including funnel cake fries. @CapRadioNews https://t.co/vS356BKQLt

name: NPR
text:
Mike Penceâ€™s chief of staff owns stocks in at least 23 companies doing work linked to the White House pandemic response.

On at least two recent occasions during his work on the coronavirus task force, he has mentioned companies in which he holds stock.
https://t.co/N9g95wchCw

name: NPR
text:
Illinois is reopening some retail shops, restaurants, salons and other businesses Friday. But Chicago is delaying its limited business reopening until June 3, Mayor Lori Lightfoot said.
https://t.co/BPD2P0r3IL

name: NPR
text:
Yemen already suffers what the U.N. calls the world's most extreme humanitarian crisis. 

As the virus spreads, healthcare facilities lack everything from PPE for staff to beds for the ill to specialist expertise.
https://t.co/NwPAb8mP7Y

name: NPR
text: Amazon hired 175,000 temporary workers to deal with the online shopping spike. Now it's offering to convert 125,000 into permanent full-time employees. https://t.co/XcU1gozq5s

name: NPR
text:
Rhiannon Giddens and her partner, Francesco Turrisi, are hoping to offer us some comfort with down-home tunes in this Tiny Desk (home) concert. 

And with banjos, fiddles, a bodhrÃ¡n, and that stunning voice, it works.
